Keck Center for Advanced Microscopy and Microanalysis, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716, USA ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to the manuscript 2 Current address: Department of Chemical Engineering, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, 06800, Turkey High-throughput synthesis of a series of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts (45 bimetallic and 50 monometallic samples) consisting of nickel and one of nine different metal promoters (B, Co, Cu, Fe, Mg, Mn, Sn, V and Zn) supported on one of five different metal oxides (alumina, ceria, magnesia, silica and titania) is carried out via organometallic grafting using a robotic platform. The catalysts are evaluated for their activity and selectivity for the dry reforming of methane at a feed ratio of CH4:CO2 of 1 at 650–800 °C in a parallel flow reactor system. The type of oxide support prevails over the type of additive for both catalyst activity and stability. On Al2O3 and MgO, Fe was found to be the best promoter; on SiO2, Cu is the best promoter at 700 °C and higher, while on TiO2, Mn is found to enhance the conversion at 800 °C. On CeO2, all additives except Fe have beneficial effects. Twenty-five catalysts show > 90% methane conversion with ten catalysts showing > 95% conversion at 800 °C with the H2:CO ratios ranging from 0.8 to 1.2. Amongst the ten highest performers, NiFe/Al2O3 and NiFe/MgO are more active than Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgO, respectively and were stable over a period of 25 h at 800 °C. Characterization on the as-prepared samples reveals highly dispersed phase, while after reduction in H2, highly dispersed and reduced nickel particles up to 10 nm are formed. The particles do not increase in size under dry reforming reaction conditions at 800 °C. An increased hydrogen consumption observed during H2-TPR of the nickel particles is positively correlated with methane conversion for Al2O3-based catalysts. The resistance to deactivation by coking and variation in coke structure are investigated by spectroscopic and microscopic methods to identify the relationship between metal promoters, alloy formation, and type of surface carbon deposits. Carbon whiskers were observed on the ten selected spent samples and are preferentially deposited on Ni rather than on the promoters. Carbon nanotube formation and metal particle removal from support were not observed to cause deactivation while amorphous carbon formation was clearly linked to catalyst deactivation, as amorphous carbon could encapsulate Ni, either on the support or at the end of the carbon nanotube. The organometallic grafting technique is an efficient and suitable technique for synthesizing highly dispersed and homogeneous phases which lead to high conversion and high durability for dry reforming of methane. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 Dry reforming Methane Promoter Nickel High throughput Deactivation Coke Raman XPS XRD SEM TEM TPR 1 Introduction Dry reforming of methane (CH4, DRM), (1), is an attractive process as it converts two greenhouse gases, CO2 and CH4, into syngas (CO and H2) [1] which can be subsequently transformed in fuel, via the ExxonMobil Methanol-To-Gasoline (MTG) process [2] or Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis reaction [3], or to a wide range of value-added chemicals, such as formaldehyde, acetic acid, or olefins (via the Methanol-To-Olefins process, MTO) [2,3]. DRM is a highly endothermic reaction that requires high operating temperatures, 700–850 °C, which causes rapid catalyst deactivation due to metal sintering and carbon deposition. To minimize the impact of carbon deposition, small amounts of H2S or large amounts of steam can be added to the CH4/CO2 feed [4]. Dry reforming: (1) CH 4 + CO 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 ∆ H 298 0 = 247 kJ / mol Various types of catalysts are reported in the literature for the DRM process including zeolites, spinels, perovskites, hydrotalcite, pyrochlore, and oxide supported-precious or base metals [4]. Nickel is an attractive catalyst for the DRM process due to its wide availability and low cost; however, nickel catalysts are more susceptible to deactivation by carbon deposition and sintering than noble metal catalysts under reaction conditions. The consensus in literature is that the most active and durable Ni catalysts consist of small Ni nanoparticles [3–7]. In particular, small Ni nanoparticles or isolated single-atoms have been shown to inhibit carbon deposition [4,6,8,9] due to a higher ratio of Ni atoms in the edge position than the surface positions that favor the activation of methane, whereas larger clusters favor the formation of carbon nano-filaments [4,10]. Together with small particle size, a high degree of reduction of Ni0 also contributes to good performance [7,11–13]. Moderate loadings of non-precious metal additives not only add new active sites, but can increase nickel dispersion [11,14,15] or resistance to coking by enhancing the basicity [7,16–19], increasing the oxygen storage capacity [11,19,20], by forming alloys [14,21], through selective poisoning [14,18,21], by inhibiting the formation of NiAl2O4 through coating of the Al2O3 [22], and reducing the strength of the Ni-CO bond, which has been shown to block active sites [23]. Some examples of promoters reported in the literature include Cu [24,25], Mn [18,24], Fe [24], Co [4,6,17,24–26], Sn [14,18,21], Mg [7,13,22,27,28], Ce [11,16,28–31], K [18,32], and B [9,12,15,33]. In most cases, the promoter loading is kept below a monolayer coverage to avoid blocking the active sites [11]. The choice of the support also plays an important role by providing anchoring sites, high surface area, better thermal stability, increased oxygen storage capacity [6,11,19,27], and higher basicity which increases carbon resistance [26]. Standard techniques for synthesizing Ni catalysts, such as incipient wetness impregnation often lead to formation of Ni agglomerates. More advanced syntheses techniques have been reported, such as sonochemical precipitation [34], sol-gel [18], microemulsion [35], surfactant assistant and polyol [26], atomic or molecular layer deposition [36,37], co-precipitation with reflux digestion, and non-thermal plasma [25] which provide a better control of Ni particle sizes. When adding promoters to the Ni, it is important to achieve a homogeneous distribution of the promoters and a close proximity to Ni, to ensure an ensemble effect [30]. Recently, silica-supported core-shell catalysts have been shown to inhibit Ni sintering due to site confinement and resulted in reduced carbon deposition [38]. However, there are issues with the synthesis of core-shell catalysts including controlling the core size and shell thickness, low loading of metal obtained, and hindrance of the metal sites by the shell [39]. Surface organometallic chemistry (SOMC) [40], which utilizes organometallic compounds to graft metal atoms onto oxide supports at surface concentrations of less than a monolayer coverage, has been shown to produce isolated metal atoms or highly-dispersed nanoscale particles with a narrow particle size distribution depending on the heat treatment [41]. Highly dispersed metal particles tend to minimize surface energy by increasing interaction with the support which help stabilize the particles from sintering [34,42]. Furthermore, isolated Ni atoms are more resistant to carbon deposition due to their ability to activate C-H bond in CH4 but to avoid methane decomposition into carbon [8]. Several forms and morphologies of coke deposit have been observed and identified [7,43–45] such as pyrolytic coke, amorphous coke, whiskers, gum, encapsulating coke, carbide-like coke, etc. The two general morphologies of coke are islands (either graphitic or amorphous) and filamentous whiskers, each of which have different mechanisms for catalyst deactivation. Generally, carbonaceous islands encapsulate metal active sites, and filamentous whiskers push the metal active sites out of the support material. Once the type of coke deposit is identified, it is important to correlate the activity of the catalyst with the corresponding type of deposited carbon. For example, the formation of graphitic nanotubes, or whiskers, has been cited as the cause for catalyst deactivation. While this is the case for many systems [46–48], recent studies in hydrocarbon reforming with transition metals have shown that whisker formation does not always deactivate the catalyst [47,49]. When whiskers form, they may lift the metal site out of the support, and if the particle is not encapsulated, it could remain active [50,51]. To rationalize these observations, the details of the mechanism of dry reforming should be considered. It includes two integral reactions: the decomposition of methane and the recombination of carbon dioxide. The decomposition of methane is typically a step-wise process that occurs on the active metal site, forming H2 product and leaving CHx, and C on the metal surface [52]. Thus, methane decomposition, while driving the formation of hydrogen, is also a source of carbon deposition. The recombination of CO2 often proceeds on reactive support materials (such as MgO, Al2O3, CeO2, and ZrO2) or, in the case of less reactive support materials such as SiO2, on the active metal site. Our approach is to enhance catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts, in terms of activity, stability and coke resistance by depositing a submonolayer of promoters with the aim of increasing nickel dispersion, reducibility, and interaction with the modified-support. Specifically, we report the systematic and high-throughput organometallic grafting synthesis of 95 different combinations of Ni and promoters such as B, Cu, Co, Fe, Mn, Sn, Mg, V, and Zn and oxide-supports including Al2O3, CeO2, MgO, SiO2 and TiO2 by first grafting of the promoter using as an organometallic precursors followed by calcination, and finally depositing the Ni using bis(N,N'-di-t-butylacetamidinato)nickel(II) as metal precursor. These promoters and supports were selected based on a review of the literature for their ability to minimize sintering and coking. Particularly, B can facilitate carbon removal, thus improve coking resistance [15,33]. Similarly, Ce is a carbon suppressor, and it increases Ni reducibility and enhances dispersion [11,16]. Sn was reported to enhance the dispersion of Ni and hence retard sintering [14]. In addition, alloys of Sn and Ni modeled by DFT, were found to suppress carbon deposits [21]. Co have been found to increase the activity and stability [17,24,25]. Koo reported that Mg forms a stable MgAl2O4 spinel phase which is stable at high temperature and prevents the formation of coke [28]. Its high resistance to coking [7] is also due to its strong basicity [13]. It was also reported that MgO increased the reducibility of Ni [7]. Core shell Zn-based Ni catalysts produced from ZIF-8 was found to be stable over 140 h [39]. Cu and Mn are reported with varying outcomes [18,24,25] but are still of interest. These catalysts were then screened using a parallel flow reactor for the DRM reaction at temperatures ranging from 650° to 800°C to identify any combination(s) of promoter and support that lead to an improvement in reactivity and stability over the non-promoted nickel catalysts for producing syngas. Then by thorough characterization of the coke deposit on highly active catalysts, we can further understand the complex chemistry responsible for catalytic performance, which can be utilized to efficiently design future catalytic systems. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 High-throughput catalysis synthesis High-throughput combinatorial screening employing robotic platforms for synthesis and parallel reactor systems for testing offers an opportunity to explore a broader and more diverse chemical design space than conventional experimental approaches with exceptional reproducibility and a minimal investment in materials, and possibly generate a large data set for machine learning efforts [19]. An automated synthesis platform (CM3 Core Module deck, Unchained Labs Inc.) housed in a custom-built N2-filled glovebox (MB 200B, MBraun), shown in Fig. S1, was used for the catalyst syntheses. The CM3 performed both solid and liquid dispensing as well as on-deck stirring. A two-step surface organometallic chemistry (SOMC) process was used for depositing the promoters and Ni onto each of the supports as shown in Scheme 1. The 50 monometallic and 45 bimetallic compositions are listed in Table 1. 2.1.1 Deposition of the promoters onto the supports by SOMC For each support, the promoter concentration was targeted to provide ca. 50% of a monolayer coverage. 600 mg of support was loaded into an 8-mL glass vial along with a magnetic stir bar. Under stirring, the solid supports were pre-wetted with dry toluene to ensure homogeneous deposition of the organometallic precursors. Various stock solutions of organometallic precursors (B, Cu, Co, Fe, Mn, Sn, Mg, V, Zn) (see SI for precursors and Table S1 for support characterization) in toluene were dispensed into each vial by the CM3 automation platform. After dispensing the stock solution containing the precursor, additional toluene was dispensed to adjust the total liquid volume to 4 mL. The well plates containing 24 vials were manually placed on the shaker plate and shaken at a rate of 600 rpm for 24 h. The well plates were then placed in a centrifuge (Speedvac Concentrator, Savant SPD121P, ThermoElectron) for 10 min after which the supernatant was removed manually, followed by adding 2-mL of fresh toluene. This procedure was repeated 5 times. The well plates were transferred from the glovebox and placed open-capped on another shaker (Digital Pulse Mixer, Glas-Col) in a fume hood and left to dry for 2 days. After air drying, the samples were calcined in air at 450 °C for 2 h. 2.1.2 Deposition of nickel by SOMC The dried solids were then brought back into the glovebox for the addition of bis(N,N'-di-t-butylacetamidinato)nickel(II) to target 50% of a monolayer coverage. The same procedure was repeated as above without calcination as the final step. Each vial was barcoded for tracking and stored outside the glovebox in the air. 2.2 Characterization Metal analysis was performed at the Northwestern University Quantitative Bio-element Imaging Center. Quantification of Ni, Fe, Co, Cu, Mg, Sn and Zn was accomplished using ICP-OES of acid digested samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy studies were performed on a K-Alpha+ XPS System (Thermo Scientific) in the Surface Analysis Facility at the University of Delaware using Al K-Alpha X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV) at a 35.3° takeoff angle with respect to the analyzer. The high-resolution spectra were collected at 0.1 eV/step with the pass energy of 60 eV. The survey spectra were collected over the energy range of 0 − 1000 eV. Casa XPS (version 2.3.16) software was utilized to analyze all the raw data. The XPS scale was calibrated using the carbon 1 s peak at 284.6 eV [53,54]. Surface concentrations were determined using the following equation: x j = A j / S j ∑ ( A j / S j ) where xj is the surface concentration, Aj is the peak area, and Sj is the sensitivity factor. H2-TPR studies were carried out in an Altamira (AMI-100) system. Samples of 40 mg were loaded into a quartz U-tube reactor. The H2-TPR profiles were obtained by flowing H2/Ar mixture at 50 mL/min from 30° to 700°C at 10 °C/min. The hydrogen consumption was monitored quantitatively using a thermal conductivity detector. The crystalline phase compositions of H2-TPR reduced catalysts were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) using a Bruker Diffractometer D8 Advance operating with the following parameters: Cu Kα radiation of 40 mA, 40 kV, Kλ = 0.15418 nm, 2θ scanning range of 10–70°, a scan step size of 0.0018º and a time of 1 s per step. The sample was placed on a zero-background silicon holder (MTI Corp.) for analysis. Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA) were carried using a TGA Discovery (TA Instruments) coupled with a mass spectrometer (QMS200, Stanford Research Systems) with 5 mL/min dried air from room temperature to 800 °C. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed with a Zeiss Auriga 60 SEM in the Keck Center for Advanced Microscopy and Microanalysis at the University of Delaware. Images were collected with an accelerating voltage of 3 kV and a working distance of 10.0 mm. Electron dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was performed in conjunction with SEM in the Keck Center for Advanced Microscopy and Microanalysis at the University of Delaware. Images were collected with an accelerating voltage of 16 kV, except for samples containing copper (17 kV), and zinc (18 kV). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed with a Talos F200C TEM connected to a Thermofisher Scientific Ceta 16 M camera. Powder samples were dusted onto a 300 mesh copper grid with carbon film support and then loaded into the TEM, which was operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV in scanning tunneling electron microscopy mode (STEM) to obtain high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) images. Raman spectroscopy investigation was performed using a LabRAM HR Evolution Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm laser and 1800 grooves/mm grating. Solid samples were deposited onto a glass slide and placed on a Marzhauser stage, and spectral data was collected from 400 to 3000 wavenumbers. Scans were collected in triplicate to perform statistical analysis. An amorphous carbon reference was measured using carbon black carefully analyzed from an ANASYS S instrument test sample for NanoIR containing carbon black/epoxy and PMMA/PS/epoxy standard on flat ZnS, and only the carbon black sample spot was analyzed. To determine the percentage of amorphous carbon, the background of each spectrum (1000 cm-1 to 1800 cm-1) was corrected with a straight line to bring both ends of the spectrum to a y-intercept of zero. The amorphous carbon spectrum was then fit to each bimetallic catalyst Raman spectrum, aligning both intensities at 1480 cm-1. The integral under the curve was calculated for the catalyst spectrum and the fitted amorphous carbon spectrum using Origin software, and the area under the spectrum to determine the percent of amorphous carbon. The amorphous carbon spectrum was then subtracted from the catalyst spectrum, and the D and G bands were fit with Lorentzian peaks. The G’ and D’ bands were also fit but the resulting observations were not additionally analyzed in this study. 2.3 High-throughput catalysis screening A 16-channel high-throughput fixed bed system (Flowrence® from Avantium) was used for the catalytic experiments (Fig. S1). All gases were purchased from Airgas and were UHP grade. Composition of the cylinders is chosen based on a minimum pressure of 2000 psig, which allows a high head pressure over the 16-split feed for equal distribution of gases in all reactors. 50 mg catalyst was mixed with 50 mg diluent (SiC, 320 grit, Alfa Aesar) and loaded into a quartz reactor (2 mm ID, 30 mm length). Total flowrates for each reactor of 7 mL/min were used; of which 6 mL/min CO2/CH4/Ar (10/10/80 vol%), and 1 mL/min He (CH4:CO2 = 1:1), which gives a GHSV of 3200 h-1 and 8.4 L/g.h. Catalysts were pre-reduced with 10% H2/N2 for 2 h at 800 °C at a flowrate of 15 mL/min. The temperatures tested were 650–800 °C (5 °C/min) with an increment of 50 °C, followed by a stability testing at 800 °C for 24 h. The temperature for the stability testing was chosen according to (1) literature reports [6,12–14,16,21,25,38,39], and optimization of temperature using experimental design [55], and (2) to reduce coke formation due to the Boudouard reaction occurring below 700 °C [5], and (3) to accelerate thermal sintering. Analysis of the effluents was carried out one reactor outlet at a time, so the 16 catalysts were exposed to each testing temperature for a period of 3 h. One GC analysis was taken at each temperature and 7 additional ones at 800 °C for the stability evaluation. The reproducibility of the catalyst testing was evaluated by running one sample four times and it was found that the conversion deviated by less than 2%. Blank quartz tube and SiC diluent were tested and did not show any significant conversion (less than 1% CH4 conversion at 800 °C). The conversion of CH4 (CO2) was calculated based on the concentration of CH4 (CO2) in the inlet and outlet of gas flow using He as internal standard using the following equation: CH 4 conversion ( % ) = ( [ CH 4 in ] − [ CH 4 out ) ] x 100 [ CH 4 in ] Carbon balance was calculated to evaluate the amount of C missing as follow: C balance ( % ) = ( moles CH 4 out + moles CO 2 out + moles CO out ) moles CO 2 in + moles CO in 3 Results and discussion 3.1 High throughput catalysis screening Catalyst performances were obtained using a set of 16 parallel flow reactors. The catalysts were first reduced in situ at 800 °C in a stream of 10% H2/Ar for 2 h to reduce the Ni from 2+ to the catalytically active metallic state. The reduced catalysts were then tested for the DRM initially at 650 °C and then raising the temperature in 50 °C increments up to 800 °C at a CH4:CO2 ratio of 1:1 and GHSV of 8.4 L/g∙h. At these temperatures, the equilibrium methane conversion ranged from 94.9% at 650 °C to 98.7% at 800 °C, calculated by HSC software (HSC Chemistry 5.11) with respect to the dilution conditions (CO2/CH4/Ar = 10/10/80 vol%), used in our study (Fig. S2). The conversions of CH4 for all the Ni-containing samples as well as the calculated theoretical conversions are shown in Fig. 1. MgO-supported catalysts consistently showed amongst the highest conversion at all temperatures. TiO2-supported catalysts consistently showed the lowest conversion at all temperatures despite this oxide being a redox support, which should increase the activity for DRM [34]. At 650 °C, there is more variation in conversion due to effects of the promoter. It is evidently clear that the effects of additives vary depending on the oxide supports and that the support effect prevails over that of the additive. On Al2O3, Fe is consistently the best promoter at any temperature, while Mg is at both 750 and 800 °C. On CeO2, all the additives have beneficial effect except Fe. Ni/MgO shows a high methane conversion to start with, so the effect of additives is relatively mild. For instance, at 700 °C, B, Co, Fe and Zn show some improvements, while at 750 °C, it is Fe and Zn, and finally at 800 °C, Fe is the only additive to enhance the conversion. On SiO2, there is no effect from the additive at 650 °C; however, at higher temperature, Cu is the only additive that has a beneficial effect. On TiO2, at 650 °C, 700 °C and 750 °C, the conversions for all catalysts are below 15%. At 800 °C, Mn is the best promoter with a conversion of 51% compared to Ni alone with 24%. Fig. S3 shows the relationship between the conversion of methane and carbon dioxide at 800 °C for all combinations investigated. The activities of the catalysts cover a wide range of conversions. Above 70% conversion, most catalysts are located above the diagonal, i.e. the carbon dioxide conversion is higher than that of methane, due to the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction which is more favorable at higher temperatures (2). Reverse water-gas shift: (2) CO 2 ⁢ + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ∆ H 298 0 = 41 kJ / mol At high conversion, catalysts supported on the more basic MgO fall below the diagonal whereas catalysts supported on the more acidic SiO2 are well above the diagonal. This observation can be explained by the fact that bases are known to accelerate the decomposition of formate to H2 and CO2 which should enhance the WGS rates [56] and by increased oxidation of surface carbon in DRM [57]. The generation of steam by the RWGS reaction may be beneficial enhancing the coke removal during DRM [5]. In order to understand the effect of each promoter on a specific support, it is more suitable to compare the performance of the promoted NiM/support catalysts to the unpromoted Ni/support catalysts by comparing the ratio of their conversions (x axis = CH4 conversion for NiM/support / CH4 conversion for corresponding Ni/support and y axis = CO2 conversion for NiM/support / CO2 conversion for corresponding Ni/support) as shown in Fig. 2 for 800 °C and in Fig. S4 for 650, 700 and 750 °C. The upper right quadrant is where both ratios are above 1, i.e., CH4 and CO2 conversion of the promoted catalysts are greater than the CH4 and CO2 conversions of the unpromoted catalyst, which means the effect of promoter is beneficial on both CH4 and CO2 conversions. As mentioned earlier, the data points for each support are more spread out at lower temperature and tend to gravitate into clusters at high temperatures, especially for Al2O3, CeO2, MgO and SiO2, but not so much for TiO2 (Fig. S4). This is because for these supports, at 800 °C, the experimental conversion approached that of the theoretical one, while for TiO2 the conversions are still low. At 800 °C, the NiM/support that show an improvement compared to Ni/support are Ni(B, Co, Cu, Mg, Mn, Sn, V and Zn)/CeO2 compared to Ni/CeO2 and Ni(Co, Cu, Fe, Mg, Mn, Sn and V)/TiO2 compared to Ni/TiO2. NiFe/Al2O3, NiCu/SiO2, and NiFe/MgO also show some improvement, however, to a lesser extent. However, these catalysts might not be the best overall performers when comparing amongst all catalysts. The reaction produces mainly CO and H2. It is important to show the H2/CO syngas ratio and the carbon balance ( Fig. 3), which are indicative of coke formation. The H2/CO ratio exhibits whether the hydrogen is being produced by the methane cracking (3) accompanied by carbon deposition or by reaction with CO2. A higher H2/CO ratio will result if more of the H2 is produced by methane cracking and/or if carbon is being deposited by the Boudouard reaction (4) [58]. This is the case for NiCu/Al2O3 and NiCu/SiO2. Methane cracking: (3) CH 4 ↔ C + 2 H 2 ∆ H 298 0 = 260.5 kJ / mol Boudouard reaction: (4) 2 CO ↔ C + CO 2 ∆ H 298 0 = − 172.4 kJ / mol Lower H2/CO ratios can be caused by carbon deposits reacting with CO2 resulting in the formation of CO. In addition, the RWGS would also lower the H2/CO ratio [58]. There is a clear inverse linear relationship between the carbon balance and the H2/CO produced, i.e., the samples that show the highest carbon balance (mostly SiO2- and Al2O3-supported catalysts) produced a H2/CO ratio between 0.8 and 1. This can be explained by the fact that excess production of CO2 ensures the oxidation of any deposited coke into more CO, therefore the most coke-resistant catalysts are the ones that produce slightly more CO than H2 [59]. The stability of all catalysts was evaluated at 800 °C by maintaining this temperature for ~25 h after testing at 650, 700, 750 and 800 °C as shown in Fig. S5 (a-d). These results indicate that the grafting synthesis method is successful in creating highly stabilized active sites [60]. While all the NiM/TiO2 combinations showed initial poor activity, there seems to be an activation step over a period of at least 20 h, which leads to much higher conversion (Fig. S5e). This behavior could be ascribed to the surface restructuring or further Ni2+ reduction when the catalysts are exposed to the reaction mixture [30]. Table S2 summarizes the initial methane conversion, after 25 h on stream and the activity decay, which is calculated based on the difference between initial and final methane conversion. While there are substantial promoter effects on ceria support, NiM/CeO2 suffers from strong deactivation over the course of the run. Ceria is well known for its superior reducibility, but the elevated operation temperature may affect its structural properties [61]. Other samples suffering from substantial deactivation are NiSn/SiO2 and NiZn/SiO2. Tin seems only to have a positive effect on MgO, while on other supports it has the opposite effect. Sn was also reported to be an effective promoter for Ni/MgO [30]. Twenty-six catalysts showed over 90% methane conversion after 25 h, 10 of which showed over 95% methane conversion at 800 °C ( Fig. 4). In particular, NiFe/Al2O3 with a 99% conversion (close to equilibrium) is one of the best catalysts reported at that temperature [36,62,63]. For the 10 best performing catalysts, the activity of the corresponding M/support (before the addition of Ni) was evaluated at 800 °C (Table S2), to rule out any substantial contribution of the promoter itself. Cu/Al2O3 and V/Al2O3 had the highest initial conversions with 61% and 51%, respectively, while all the other M/support show methane conversion less than 35%. However, for all these, their conversions are well below the conversions obtained for their Ni counterparts. To investigate the reasons behind high catalytic activity, full characterization studies of the as prepared, reduced and spent catalysts were conducted on the 10 catalysts shown in Fig. 4. 3.2 Characterization of the selected catalysts The characterization of the as-prepared catalysts by TEM, XRD and XPS is presented in the SI. 3.2.1 Characterization of the reduced catalysts The XRD patterns of Al2O3, Ni/Al2O3, Ni/M/Al2O3, MgO, NiM/MgO and NiM/MgO after H2-TPR up to 700 °C are shown in Fig. 5. Peaks located at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.8° can be assigned to Ni0 (PDF 00-001-1258). There are no NiO peaks (2θ = 37.2°, 43.2°, 62.8° PDF 01-073-1523) indicating that Ni is mostly reduced and/or that the concentration of NiO is below the detection limit of XRD. On Al2O3-based samples, sharps Ni0 peaks are seen for all samples except for Ni/Al2O3, NiFe/Al2O3 and NiMg/Al2O3 indicative of a more distributed Ni phase due to smaller particles or low crystallinity of Ni phases, in agreement with higher interactions of Ni observed during H2-TPR (Fig. S9) for these samples. In addition, NiFe/Al2O3 is particularly less crystalline than Ni/Al2O3 and Al2O3 support indicative of homogeneous coverage of Ni-Fe onto alumina. Based on ICP data (Table S4), there are 43% sites occupied by Fe, which is closed to the target value (50%). There was no phase associated with the promoters due to their low loading (except for Fe) and dispersed phase. Even for Fe-based samples (NiFe/Al2O3 and NiFe/MgO) which contains higher loading of Fe, there was no phase associated with Fe. On MgO-based samples, only NiV/MgO shows some Ni0. Similarly to NiFe/Al2O3, NiFe/MgO presents lower crystallinity compared to MgO, indicative of an even coverage of iron species onto MgO. A good correlation between various characterization techniques (H2-TPR, XRD, elemental analyses) and the catalytic activity for the Al2O3- and MgO-based samples is observed. On Al2O3, the low-temperature reduction peak by H2-TPR combined with observed Ni0 particles by XRD, for all Ni/promoter/Al2O3, except for Ni, NiFe and NiMg, confirmed the presence of larger particles in these samples which are responsible for lower initial methane conversion (Fig. S5a). In contrast, NiFe/Al2O3 and NiMg/Al2O3 showed highly dispersed nickel species that have stronger interaction with the promoter and higher reductive capability necessary for producing active metallic nickel, hence enabling high initial conversion. In addition, due to the high site coverage by Fe, Fe acts as a “precoat” for nickel [22]. On MgO, all samples have initially high methane conversion (Fig. S5c); except for NiV, which showed a low initial conversion probably due to larger Ni0 particles compared to the others, as seen by XRD, and a particular slow activation under reaction conditions, certainly due to hard-to-reduce Ni species observed by H2-TPR. On both Al2O3 and MgO, loadings of Fe were particularly higher than for the other promoters (Table S4). The layer of iron onto Al2O3 (and MgO), as observed by XRD, allows for nickel to be more dispersed. TEM images of some of the reduced samples (800 °C in a stream of 10% H2/inert for 2 h) ( Fig. 6a-d) demonstrate that dispersed nanoparticles, in the sizes ranging from a few nm to 10 nm, were present on the surface, while none was observed on the as-prepared samples (Fig. S6). 3.2.2 Characterization of nickel and promoters on the spent catalysts EDX investigations of spent catalysts of the 10 best samples (CH4 conversion > 95%), Ni/Al2O3 NiFe/Al2O3, NiMg/Al2O3, Ni/MgO, NiCo/MgO, NiCu/MgO, NiFe/MgO, NiSn/MgO, NiMg/MgO, NiZn/MgO are summarized in Figs. S11-S20. Since the materials were diluted with SiC for catalytic studies, SiC is also present on the images. In order to distinguish SiC carbide particles from the catalytic materials studied, elemental EDS mapping of silicon is also included in all these figures. Both Ni and promoters are well dispersed and present at the same location which may cause the synergistic effects that were discussed above, even after DRM. This indicates that the synthesis method was successful in creating a homogeneous distribution of the promoters and Ni in close proximity. TEM images of the spent catalysts (Fig. 6e–h) show that dispersed nanoparticles, in the sizes ranging from a few nm to 10 nm, which were already present on the surface after H2-reduction at 800 °C remained stable after DRM reaction, indicating that the reaction conditions did not lead to further agglomeration. XRD of spent Ni/Al2O3 only showed the presence of Ni0, some graphitic carbon and SiC which was used as the diluent (Fig. S21). There was no phase corresponding to NiAl2O4. Table S4 describes the surface (XPS) and bulk (ICP) percentages of metal in the catalysts. ICP analysis shows that nickel was present in significant amounts, ranging from 1.11 wt% to 4.26 wt%, and nickel/promoter ratios show relatively similar concentrations of promoter metal, except for magnesium in NiMg/Al2O3. Certain metals such as Cu and Co likely have low rates of diffusion into bulk MgO, which causes higher apparent concentrations on the surface as opposed to the bulk catalyst. Consistent with the XRD investigation, after the reduction step followed by DRM (from 650° to 800°C), a new peak is observed by XPS at ~853 eV for all catalysts (Fig. S8), which can be easily assigned to metallic nickel [64–67] indicating that nickel was reduced in the reaction process. XPS analysis was performed ex situ, therefore oxidized Ni 2p3/2 peaks are observed as well. It should be noted that the signal-to-noise ratio for the spent catalysts is much lower compared to the same samples before activation. Unfortunately, this is explained by the overall drastic decrease of the signal due to carbon deposits (vide infra). The details of the formation of surface carbon deposits are presented below, but it is worth mentioning at this point that in all cases considered, the amount of carbon produced on a surface of catalysts is substantial, as also confirmed by SEM images presented in Fig. S22. Given that XPS is only sensitive to few topmost nanometers of the sample, several nanometers of carbon deposit can block the signal from nickel and promoters completely. Nevertheless, using appropriate parameters for collecting XPS spectra, the data in Fig. S8 were collected for the samples following the catalytic trials. The main evaluation is in the Ni/promoter ratio, given in Table S5 for samples following DRM process. For all the samples studied, the Ni/promoter and Ni/support ratios significantly decrease after DRM, while the decrease in promoter/support ratios are comparatively small. This observation is consistent with nickel being less accessible to XPS interrogation and suggests that carbon is deposited to cover nickel preferentially compared to the promoters (since otherwise the nickel/promoter ratio would remain unchanged). In other words, this indicates that carbon is depositing preferentially over or encapsulates nickel-rich surface, also explaining the low signal-to-noise ratio within the Ni 2p spectral region for the spent samples. This is reasonable because nickel is the active site for methane decomposition. 3.3 Characterization and analysis of surface carbon species 3.3.1 Identification of surface carbon species While the ten most active catalysts have been identified (methane conversion >95%) and characterization of the metal shows well dispersed, reduced nickel as the DRM active site, the question remained why nickel sites are still active after significant coke deposition, which was observed by SEM (Fig. S22). Abundant whisker formation is typically associated with catalyst deactivation because it removes the metal particle from the support [46–48], but this is incongruent with our observations. To answer this fundamental question and gain further understanding of the coke formation mechanism, we thoroughly analyzed the surface carbon that was formed during highly efficient DRM catalysis. Fig. 7 shows the details of Raman spectral features of the active catalysts following 24 h under the DRM reaction conditions (650–800 °C, then 800 °C for 24 h), as well as the diluent used to pack the reactor, silicon carbide (blue line). The catalytic activity of these catalysts did not decrease noticeably during the catalytic study; however, as will be shown below, all of them had substantial coke deposits (Figs. S22). Due to carbon present in the silicon carbide diluent, the full quantification of carbon was not possible based on these data alone; however, Raman spectroscopy offers an opportunity to perform a full analysis of carbon formed during dry reforming, which is distinct from carbidic carbon, as demonstrated in Fig. 7. Three major peaks can be clearly identified and used for analysis: the D-band (1343 cm-1), the G-band (1574 cm-1) and the G’-band (2690 cm-1). Van Santen et al. [68] have identified three different carbonaceous species formed upon methane decomposition, denoted as Cα, Cβ, and Cγ. Hydrogenated at lower temperatures, Cα is carbidic surface carbon, and is the most reactive. Cβ is hydrogenated at higher temperatures and represents less reactive amorphous carbon on the surface. The most unreactive surface carbon is Cγ, which represents graphitic carbon. Raman spectroscopy specifically has been useful in the identification of coke formation, with experimental studies mainly focused on D and G bands. Analysis of the D-band, which represents disordered carbon, and the G-band, which represents graphitic carbon, reveals the type of coke present on the surface following a DRM reaction. Guo et al. [69] reported that for Ni/MgAl2O4 catalysts, both the D-band and G-band were recorded, and thermal oxidation decreased the D-band at lower temperatures and the G-band at higher temperatures. The D-band was assigned to Cα and Cβ type carbon, and the G-band was assigned to Cγ type carbon. By comparing the Raman spectra of reacted catalysts to SiC diluent and as-prepared catalyst (Fig. S23), it can be concluded that the D, G, and G’ peaks are not present prior to the DRM reaction, and therefore must arise from carbon that is deposited on the surface during the DRM process. With this assumption, the D, G, and G’-bands can be used as quantitative indicators in characterization of coke formation. The D- band of carbon (Fig. 7, ~1343 cm-1) is a double-resonance Raman effect observed from sp2 carbon, typically assigned to disordered carbon [70]. In the presence of carbon nanotubes, it may indicate defects in the nanotube walls, such as bends or curves [71]. While the D-band is often assigned to amorphous carbon, the presence of purely amorphous carbon would be represented by a very broad peak beneath and in-between the D and G peaks [72,73], which is not seen in any of the ten active DRM catalysts. Therefore, the disordered carbon present on the catalysts must be associated with graphite, whether in the planar structure or the nanotube structure. The G-band of carbon (Fig. 7, ~1574 cm-1) is an in-plane ring stretching mode characteristic of graphite [74]. At higher wavenumbers (~1600 cm-1), the G band is thought to represent smaller clusters of graphite, while pure graphite has a single G peak at 1575 cm-1 and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) have the G feature at ~1580 cm-1 [72,74,75]. Both G features of pure graphite and MWNTs are consistent with the experimental G peaks observed in Fig. 7, and the presence of carbon nanotubes can be confirmed with SEM (Fig. S22). A small shoulder peak on the right of the G-band is also observed for each sample. This feature is known as the D’ band and is a result of an intravalley scattering process with either a phonon or a defect. It can be used to characterize disorder in crystals, but was not examined in this study separately [76]. TGA studies were also performed and though unable to quantify the coke deposit due to SiC diluent, detected two main carbon species (Fig. S24) which is in agreement with Raman characterization of the D and G types of carbon. The D/G band ratio is regularly used to characterize the crystallinity of coke formation, with lower D/G ratios corresponding to a higher degree of graphitization. In the context of catalysis, larger D/G ratios are often considered favorable because defected carbon is easier to remove from the catalyst surface by oxidation. This is demonstrated clearly by TPO studies which show that graphitic carbon is the most difficult coke to remove during oxidation [69]. The G’-band corresponds to a two-phonon, second order scattering that describes long-range order of crystalline carbon. The G’ feature is present in both graphite and carbon nanotubes, but the Raman shift is reportedly less for nanotubes than graphite (2738 cm-1 to 2715 cm-1), with the nanotube assignment closer to the experimental G’ peak (~2690 cm-1) observed in Fig. 7 [75]. Previous studies have been performed on the Raman characterization of metal oxides Ni [77,78], Cu [79,80], Mg [81,82], Fe [83,84], Co [85,86], Sn [87–89], and Zn [90,91]. However possible Raman signatures of these oxide materials that potentially could be present in very small quantities are expected to be completely overshadowed by the presence of carbon. The Raman signal of support materials MgO and Al2O3 should also be addressed. Magnesium oxide has been investigated by Raman spectroscopy, and the MgO peaks were distinct from the carbon-based D, G, and G’ peaks [92]. The main MgO peak is observed at 1557 cm-1, shifted downward from the typical G-band seen in Fig. 7 at 1574 cm-1, and a weak peak around 1300 cm-1 could potentially overlap with the D-band. However, the distinct broad band around 1930 cm-1 recorded in MgO powders was not observed in this study, indicating that the large amount of carbon signal dominated the spectra. A study by Maneshian et al. [93] demonstrated that alumina similarly does not have strong Raman bands that would overlap with carbon signal. 3.3.2 Correlation between coke species and catalytic activity To fully understand the method of deactivation for the bimetallic grafted catalysts, four additional catalysts were studied with percent methane conversions ranging from 12.8% and 80.8%. The D and G peaks for these catalysts are shown in Fig. 8. The amorphous carbon peak can be seen as the broad peak underlying the D and G peaks [72,73]. This “fingerprint” of amorphous carbon was not observed on the active catalysts, such as NiZn/MgO. The D-bands for active catalysts are aligned at 1343 cm-1, while the G-band for NiV/SiO2, NiMn/SiO2, and NiZn/SiO2 is at ~1581 cm-1, shifted to higher wavenumbers from 1574 cm-1. Shifting of the G-band to higher wavenumbers has been linked to graphite clustering and was described by Ferrari et al. as a step in the process of the amorphization of carbon [74]. The amount of amorphous carbon was quantified using a carbon black standard, and the amorphous carbon was fit to each spectrum to determine the percent of amorphous carbon formed during the dry reforming of methane. After amorphous carbon subtraction, the D and G bands are fit with Lorentzian peaks and the D/G ratio is analyzed. Fig. 9a shows the D/G Raman peak area ratios of Ni/MgO and NiM/MgO catalysts (M = B, Co, Cu, Zn, Sn, Fe, Mg), Ni/Al2O3 and NiM/Al2O3 catalysts (M = Fe, Mg), and NiM/SiO2 catalysts (M=V, Mn) with respect to percent of methane conversion. Large error bars were observed for the Raman ratios of several catalysts, which is expected for inhomogeneous carbon layers. The D/G carbon ratio initially increased with catalytic activity, peaking at ~70% conversion with NiV/SiO2, then decreasing for the highly active catalysts (clustered between 95% and 100%), indicating that optimal methane conversion is correlated with low ratios of disordered carbon to ordered graphitic carbon. This would point to increased formation of ordered carbon in the form of nanotubes. Fig. 9b shows the percentage of amorphous carbon present in the 1000 cm-1 to 1800 cm-1 range correlated to percent methane conversion, and it is clear that decreased presence of amorphous carbon correlates to higher catalytic activity. Significant amounts of carbon are clearly seen by Raman spectroscopy, yet many of the catalysts remain highly active. The G/G’ ratio was also compared, and the correlation with catalytic activity was not observed. It must be noted that the stability test was conducted following temperature increase at 650 °C, 700 °C, and 750 °C. Therefore, it is likely that coke had deposited on the surface at lower temperatures and remained during the stability test, which may explain why catalysts with low methane conversion show little deactivation over 24 h and indicates that catalytic activity was dependent mostly on the type of coke present. Ruling out sintering, which was not observed after reduction in hydrogen or dry reforming by HRTEM (Fig. 6), amorphous carbon must be involved in the deactivation mechanism, because it is not observed on the highly active catalysts studied. NiB/MgO, NiV/SiO2, NiMn/SiO2, and NiZn/SiO2 were chosen to probe the relationship between catalytic activity and carbon formation across a wide range of methane conversion, with representation of high activity catalysts (NiZn/MgO), moderate activity catalysts (NiB/MgO, NiV/SiO2), and low activity catalysts (NiMn/SiO2, NiZn/SiO2). The NiZn/MgO catalyst had an initial methane conversion above 95% which remains steady over 24 h. The NiB/MgO catalyst had an initial methane conversion close to 85%, and slowly decreased to 80% conversion. The NiV/SiO2 catalyst started around 60% methane conversion and dipped below 50% after 10 h. The conversion then returned above 65% after 15 h. NiMn/SiO2 catalyst had an initial methane conversion around 40% and remains fairly constant over 24 h. The NiZn/SiO2 catalyst had an initial methane conversion rate of approximately 30%, quickly dropped below 20%, and then steadily decreased to approximately 10% conversion (Fig. S5d). 3.3.3 Microscopy investigation of carbon formation HRTEM images of carbon deposits on the promoted nickel-based nanoparticulate catalysts supported on Al2O3 and on MgO are depicted in Fig. 10. The carbon deposits formed during the reaction have varying morphologies but are clearly dominated by the presence of carbon nanotubes (with zoomed-in examples shown for selected nanotube types in Fig. 11 and size distribution summarized in Table S6). Unpromoted high-performing catalysts Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgO, have some of the smallest average carbon nanotube diameters, and for highly active catalysts, promotion with metals increased the average diameter on both support materials. For low-performing catalysts NiZn/SiO2, NiV/SiO2, NiMn/SiO2, and NiB/MgO, average nanotube diameters were not significantly different from nanotube diameters measured on active catalysts. The three main types of nanotubes observed in this study, as shown in Figs. 11–12, are straight multi-walled nanotubes [94], bamboo-shaped nanotubes [71,94], and highly distorted nanotubes. The last category of nanotubes, which has not been thoroughly studied, is termed so because while they are recognizable as having a nanotube-like structure, they are distorted by graphite-like plates along the sides of the walls. One of the defining features of carbon nanotubes in catalysis is their ability to push metal nanoparticles out of the substrate, with the metal nanoparticle positioned at the tip of the carbon nanotube [50]. This phenomenon was observed significantly on every catalyst and each type of carbon nanotube. While not a comprehensive study, the occurrences of metal nanoparticle tips in TEM images were counted. Representative images are shown in Fig. 12 and the number of images of nanoparticles on nanotube tips are described in Table S7. However, each catalyst studied has excellent catalytic activity (≥ 95.8% CH4 conversion and ≥ 93.2% CO2 conversion). Carbon whiskers form by adsorbed atomic carbon (Cα) deposition during the dry reforming reaction. The atomic carbon polymerizes to form an amorphous polymer film (Cβ) which goes on to form filamentous carbon (Cv) [95]. Optimum temperature for decreasing the formation of coke, at the feed ratio of CO2:CH4 = 1:1, is between 870 °C and 1040 °C [5]. Therefore, at our operating conditions, i.e. 800 °C, the formation of coke is not surprising. In addition, according to equilibrium calculation (Fig. S2), the coke formation should be more prominent at 650 °C, than at higher temperatures [95]. Since the catalysts were tested first at lower temperature (650–750 °C), they may carry over coke formed at these lower temperatures. While it is unclear exactly when the carbon nanotubes formed during catalytic testing, the assumption can be made that they were formed at lower temperatures and were present as the temperature was increased to 800 °C. Even then, deactivation was not observed upon assumed formation of carbon nanotubes. Fig. 1 shows the methane conversion rates at 650 °C for the MgO and Al2O3-supported bimetallic catalysts, with none falling below 70% methane conversion. Deactivation was not observed during the entire catalytic process, and thus the lower catalytic activity should not be caused by carbon nanotube (CNT) formation. This is evident by the high activity observed at higher temperatures when CNTs are present on the surface. In DRM catalysis, there is a well-accepted understanding that carbon whisker formation results in catalyst deactivation, however a few recent studies have claimed that whisker formation does not necessarily deactivate the metallic particle because the nickel active site remains free and accessible to gaseous reactants [47,96]. There are several other deactivation mechanisms to consider besides nickel particle extraction from support. The metal particle size plays an important role, as Gohier et al. have shown [49]. Their study showed that carbon nanotube formation is dependent on particle size, with nanoparticles smaller than 5 nm catalyzing whisker growth on top of the particle in a “base-growth” mechanism, encapsulating the particle, as opposed to the whisker being formed under the particle and pushing it outwards, leaving the active site exposed. Particle sizes larger than 5 nm, such as those in this study recorded by TEM, catalyze whiskers to form in a “tip-growth” mechanism where the whisker forms under the nanoparticle, and the metal site remains at the tip of the whisker. Another alternate cause for deactivation from whisker formation is “entanglement,” where carbon nanotubes clump together and encapsulate the nanoparticle [47]. In a study by Esawi et al. [97], it was concluded that carbon nanotubes with smaller diameters were more prone to entanglement and agglomeration, leading to encapsulation of the nickel tip. Therefore, larger carbon nanotubes may be beneficial to catalytic stability. Carbon nanotube formation and metal particle removal from support were not observed to cause deactivation in this study, counter to the typical understanding of catalyst deactivation. However, amorphous carbon formation was clearly linked to catalyst deactivation, as amorphous carbon could encapsulate nickel, either on the support or at the end of the carbon nanotube. In fact, larger and more ordered carbon nanotubes may be beneficial to catalyst activity, essentially preventing the metal particle from sintering and isolating the active site, making it more accessible for reactants. This is further supported by the insignificance of catalyst support on methane conversion for highly active catalysts. Both MgO and Al2O3 supports, while known to have different surface properties, are shown to be similarly active, which could be explained if the active sites are no longer connected to the support material. 3.3.4 Explanation of deactivation mechanism While we have identified the cause of deactivation for the grafted promoted nickel catalysts (e.g. encapsulation of nickel by amorphous carbon), the question remains what causes the change in coke formation in the presence of transition metals. Gohier et al. [49] have described the mechanism of tip-growth carbon nanotube formation. Carbonaceous species adsorb on the metal surface and diffuse to the catalyst/substrate interface, though whether the diffusion is primarily bulk diffusion or surface diffusion is still unclear [96], leaving the top of the particle exposed. This process results in particle elongation and culminates in the particle being lifted from the surface. However, the role of promoter metals in the CNT formation mechanism is unclear. There is evidence that carbon deposit is preferentially attached to nickel surface sites, so it would be reasonable to assume that the tip of the carbon nanotubes contained primarily nickel, so the question remains why the presence of promoter metals resulted in larger, more disordered nanotube formation. The role of the support material in the growth of carbon nanotubes described in this work is likely limited, since many of the materials investigated remain active (and continue participate in nanotube formation) even after the catalytic nanoparticles are lifted from the surface. Thus, the cause of the differences should be in the specific structure of the nanoparticles and electronic effects of the promoters on the catalytic activity. The details of the metal-metal interactions within a nanoparticle are outside of the scope of this work; however, several important conclusions can be reached simply by evaluating the strength of key bonds formed during the process of carbon deposition. Table 2 summarizes some of the relevant metal-carbon bond strength data for the metals used in this work. With the exception of tin, Ni-C bond is the strongest among the metals investigated. Although this simplified analysis does not take into account the potentially profound non-additive effects of alloying, a general conclusion is that the nickel-rich phases or sites on nanoparticles are highly effective in binding carbonaceous species. Thus, with the literature data presented here, we propose a mechanism for coke formation in the presence of the supported grafted nickel bimetallic catalysts. It is clear that the promoter metals used in this study are adept at catalyzing the formation of carbon nanotubes independent of nickel [107–114] and therefore carbonaceous species may initially deposit on the promoter surface. However, over the course of the reaction, carbon species may migrate to form a more thermodynamically stable bond with nickel. This migration of carbon could result in the formation of larger and more disordered nanotubes, with more carbon collecting on or around the nickel sites, possibly at random directions. It may be that certain catalysts have larger nanoparticles and therefore form larger carbon nanotubes, but this was ruled out by HRTEM nanoparticle analysis of select catalysts in the corresponding study. Significant size discrepancies were not observed for catalysts containing different promoter metals and support materials. For example, NiCu/MgO has the largest average CNT size (Table S6), but the nanoparticle sizes are not significantly different from the other catalysts tested. Typically, carbon nanotube diameter is controlled by the metal catalyst particle size [115,116], but studies have shown that carbon nanotubes can form independently of particle size and depend more on the initial nucleation of carbon [117]. The promoted catalysts all remain active because the nickel site is not necessarily hindered, and larger nanotubes reduce the likelihood of deactivating entanglement. Thus, the main reason for sustained catalytic activity is the preferential formation of whiskers instead of amorphous carbon, as illustrated in Scheme 2. 4 Conclusions A series of 95 catalysts were synthesized via the organometallic grafting method using a robotic platform. Oxide supports (alumina, ceria, magnesia, silica and titania) were first grafted with 9 promoters (B, Co, Cu, Fe, Mg, Mn, Sn, V and Zr) followed by heat treatment and grafting of nickel precursor. After in-situ reduction of the catalysts at 800 °C, activity testing for the dry reforming of methane was carried out in a 16-parallel reactor system between 650 and 800 °C, followed by a stability evaluation at 800 °C for 25 h. MgO and Al2O3 supports provided the highest initial activity and stability, while the effect of promoters was affected by the type of supports. At 800 °C, over 50% of the samples showed over 90% methane conversion and 10 of these samples, NiFe/MgO, NiFe/Al2O3, NiZn/MgO, NiSn/MgO, NiMg/MgO, Ni/MgO, NiCo/MgO, Ni/Al2O3, NiCu/MgO and NiMg/Al2O3, showed over 95% conversion and good stability over a period of 25 h. NiFe/Al2O3 and NiFe/MgO were the two best performing catalysts. TEM indicated that metal species were present as highly dispersed phases in the as-prepared catalysts. The formation of dispersed nanoparticles was observed after reducing the catalysts in H2 at 800 °C. The particles did not appear to increase in size after 25-h on stream under reaction conditions at 800 °C. Methane conversion could be directly correlated with the amount of reducible nickel species as observed by H2-TPR. Spent catalysts were characterized by XPS, SEM, HRTEM and Raman spectroscopy to elucidate coke formation. Raman spectroscopy investigation revealed that promotion with transition metals resulted in an increase in D/G peak ratios and decrease in amorphous carbon ratios which correlated with an increased methane conversion. Following the growth of carbon nanotubes during the catalytic process, metal particles were observed in the carbon nanotube tips while catalytic activity remained high, pointing to an alternative source of catalyst deactivation. The main reason of deactivation for the system was determined to be amorphous carbon formation by comparison with less active catalysts MiB/MgO, NiV/SiO2, NiMn/SiO2, and NiZn/SiO2. Whisker formation was not found to deactivate the dry reforming catalysts as is typically assumed. In contrast, the size of the nanoparticles and the width of the carbon nanotubes may have reduced the likelihood of encapsulation, and the promoter metals were theorized to have played an important role in carbon nanotube formation. A mechanism is proposed, where the promoter metals facilitate the formation of surface carbonaceous species, which then migrate to nickel sites driven by the increased thermodynamic stability. Through extensive high-throughput synthesis, catalytic testing, structural characterization, and analysis of carbon deposit, several promising grafted bimetallic catalysts have been identified for future dry reforming applications, and the underlying chemistry of the catalytic surface reactions has been explored. coredata.dc:description: High-throughput synthesis of a series of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts (45 bimetallic and 50 monometallic samples) consisting of nickel and one of nine different metal promoters (B, Co, Cu, Fe, Mg, Mn, Sn, V and Zn) supported on one of five different metal oxides (alumina, ceria, magnesia, silica and titania) is carried out via organometallic grafting using a robotic platform. The catalysts are evaluated for their activity and selectivity for the dry reforming of methane at a feed ratio of CH4:CO2 of 1 at 650–800 °C in a parallel flow reactor system. The type of oxide support prevails over the type of additive for both catalyst activity and stability. On Al2O3 and MgO, Fe was found to be the best promoter; on SiO2, Cu is the best promoter at 700 °C and higher, while on TiO2, Mn is found to enhance the conversion at 800 °C. On CeO2, all additives except Fe have beneficial effects. Twenty-five catalysts show > 90% methane conversion with ten catalysts showing > 95% conversion at 800 °C with the H2:CO ratios ranging from 0.8 to 1.2. Amongst the ten highest performers, NiFe/Al2O3 and NiFe/MgO are more active than Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgO, respectively and were stable over a period of 25 h at 800 °C. Characterization on the as-prepared samples reveals highly dispersed phase, while after reduction in H2, highly dispersed and reduced nickel particles up to 10 nm are formed. The particles do not increase in size under dry reforming reaction conditions at 800 °C. An increased hydrogen consumption observed during H2-TPR of the nickel particles is positively correlated with methane conversion for Al2O3-based catalysts. The resistance to deactivation by coking and variation in coke structure are investigated by spectroscopic and microscopic methods to identify the relationship between metal promoters, alloy formation, and type of surface carbon deposits. Carbon whiskers were observed on the ten selected spent samples and are preferentially deposited on Ni rather than on the promoters. Carbon nanotube formation and metal particle removal from support were not observed to cause deactivation while amorphous carbon formation was clearly linked to catalyst deactivation, as amorphous carbon could encapsulate Ni, either on the support or at the end of the carbon nanotube. The organometallic grafting technique is an efficient and suitable technique for synthesizing highly dispersed and homogeneous phases which lead to high conversion and high durability for dry reforming of methane.
coredata.dc:title: Grafted nickel-promoter catalysts for dry reforming of methane identified through high-throughput experimentation
